awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Novel Computational Tools to Predict Anionic Pesticide and Pharmaceutical Sorption to Soil Oxides
awd_abstract_narration:
1604305 / 1603755 / 1604165
MacKay / Vasudevan / Johnston

The last decade has witnessed a radical shift in the prioritization of environmental contaminants. No longer is our primary concern non-polar compounds that persist and bioaccumulate, but the inventory of organic contaminants has expanded greatly to include many polar and ionic compounds with potential adverse ecotoxicological effects. This study offers an innovative approach to adapt computational chemical tools to the prediction of organic ligand sorption to metal oxides.

The proposed approach represents a transformative advance in the quantitative a priori prediction of sorption coefficients for polar and ionic compounds in the environment. The integration of molecular dynamics calculations to obtain quantum mechanics measures of van der Waals, electrostatic energies and solvation effects overcomes the challenge of deconvoluting coupled structure effects from experimental measures of sorption energies alone, is at the current state of the science. Furthermore, other related sorption problems provide opportunity to expand Linear Interaction Energy approximation techniques because environmental sorbent characteristics are more generalizable than protein binding site characteristics. The overarching hypothesis of the project is: that changes in organic ligand structure by the addition/removal of non-ligand group substituents impart regular changes in sorption free energy as a result of coupled hydrophobic, electronic and proximity (i.e., steric and chelation) effects that are in turn mediated by solvent effects. The ultimate goal is to quantitatively describe organic ligand sorption to oxides as a function of specific sorbate structure criteria. A novel approach is used to identify structural criteria by bridging well-established experimental techniques with innovations in computationally relevant environmental surface chemistry, and by using the representative soil oxide, goethite. Task 1: The goethite force field will be fine-tuned using density functional theory to determine accurate compound conformations for a library of test sorbates. The chosen library includes sorbates with incremental changes in structure that allow us to identify the influence of specific ligand and non-ligand structural moieties. Computational efforts will be validated by infrared spectra to delineate binding mechanisms and transmission electron microscopy to identify relevant crystal faces. Quantum mechanics calculations will be used to calculate free energies of the inner sphere complexation reaction. Task 2: Experimental measures of sorption energies, infrared spectra and goethite measures will be obtained for test sorbates sorbed to high purity goethite. Task 3: The Linear Interaction Energy approximation will be used with molecular dynamics simulations and Task 1 force fields and inner sphere binding energies to calculate van der Waals and electrostatic contributions to overall sorption free energies. Linear Interaction Energy offers significant reductions in computational cost because molecular dynamics simulations are conducted only for the bound and unbound states. van der Waals and electrostatic energies will be regressed against experimental measures of sorption free energies to generate a predictive model for sorption coefficients. Findings from Tasks 1-3 will be integrated to identify how specific structural features can be linked to regular changes in van der Waals and electrostatic energies, thereby indicating structure-sorption relationships relevant to quantitative models. The PIs will mentor graduate and undergraduate researchers through the processes of experimental design, manuscript preparation and national professional society presentations. They will also work closely with high school students and teachers to introduce sorption concepts into public education with hands-on demonstration modules of everyday applications: home drinking water treatment and pesticide application. The PIs will continue their committed record of engaging student researchers from groups underrepresented in the sciences and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The environmental fate of emerging contaminants, such as pharmaceuticals, is influenced by the sorption of these chemicals to solid phases such as soils and sediments. These chemicals may be neutral or carry a positive (cation) and/or negative (anion) at environmentally relevant pH values. Compound charge, in turn, determines the mechanism of retention (or sorption) to soils and sediments.  Advances in predictive models for neutral and cationic compound sorption have furthered our ability to anticipate the contaminant sorption.  However, our predictive capacity for anionic compound sorption is limited.

This research is a collaborative effort between three institutions was aimed at developing predictive models for quantitatively describing organic anion sorption grounded in experimental data.  The proposed predictive model relies on probe compounds and scaling factors to anticipate the sorption of charged pharmaceuticals.  At Bowdoin College, PI Vasudevan and several undergraduate students focused on identifying an appropriate probe compound that is effective at measuring site density and the baseline driving force for organic anion sorption to soils. To this end, we measured the sorption coefficient (Kd) of seven probe compounds and three pharmaceuticals to 30 soils and five pure phase minerals.   Compound negative charge develops from the deprotonation of carboxylic (-COOH to -COO-) and/or hydroxyl (-OH to -O-) groups.  We investigated pharmaceuticals that contain a single carboxyl group (ibuprofen), adjacent carboxyl and hydroxyl groups (sulfasalazine) and multiple non-adjacent carboxyl groups (carbenicillin).  The probe compound examined also contained a single carboxyl group (hydrotropic and 2-naphthoic acid), multiple non-adjacent carboxyl groups (2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid, 4,4’-oxydibenzoic acid), adjacent carboxyl or hydroxyl groups (2,3-napthalenedicarboxylic acid and 2,3-dihydroxynaphthalne), and adjacent carboxyl and hydroxyl groups (salicylic acid).  

We evaluated the effectiveness of the above-mentioned probe compounds using careful comparisons of compound sorption to soils and pure phase minerals, linear regressions between probe and pharmaceutical logKd values, and linear regressions of probe and pharmaceutical logKd values and soil properties (such as cation exchange capacity and surficial iron and aluminum oxide content).  Our analysis revealed that compounds with single carboxyl groups and multiple nonadjacent carboxyl groups sorb to distinct soil receptor sites as compared with compound with adjacent carboxyl and hydroxyl groups and adjacent hydroxyl groups.  Further compounds with single and multiple non-adjacent carboxyl groups sorb to soil surfaces via cation-bridging, with a distinct preference for bridging to exchangeable aluminum sites.  Compounds with adjacent carboxyl and hydroxyl groups sorb primarily via surface complexation to surficial iron and aluminum oxides, while cation-bridging is secondary sorption mechanism. As a result of sorption via distinct mechanisms to distinct receptors, a universal probe for anionic pharmaceutical could not be identified.  Instead, 2-naphthoic acid (with a single carboxyl group) was found to be strong probe for pharmaceuticals, such as ibuprofen, which also have single carboxyl group. Salicylic acid was found to be a strong probe for sulfasalazine, both compounds possess adjacent carboxyl and hydroxyl groups.  Carbencillin undergoes surface complexation to soils via carboxyl group and the adjacent carbonyl group on the amide and cation bridging via the carboxyl groups; a strong probe for carbenicillin could not be identified. Our results reveal that unlike cationic pharmaceuticals which sorb via a single sorption mechanism, anionic pharmaceuticals sorb to multiple receptor sites both surface complexation and cation bridging.  Hence, probe-based predictive models will have to leverage mechanism specific probe compounds for the predication of anionic pharmaceutical sorption.

This work has made important contributions to the training of next generation of scientists and engineers. Eight undergraduates have been trained in research: from posing a research question, to experimental design, data analysis, proposal and report writing, poster and oral presentations. All of the students have presented posters and oral presentations at Bowdoin College.

PI Vasudevan and her students conducted several outreach efforts. We designed hands experiments demonstrating the charge on soils and potential for organic compounds to sorb to soils, using purple cool-aid, which was a lot of fun.  We interacted with students from local elementary schools, a group of high school students connected to a sustainable oceans project, and 8th grades from the Passamaquoddy reservation in Maine.
